column1: #Text=Highway is a C++ library that provides portable SIMD/vector intrinsics.
#Text=Previously licensed under Apache 2, now dual-licensed as Apache 2 / BSD-3.
#Text=to reliably and economically push the boundaries of what is possible in
#Text=CPUs provide SIMD/vector instructions that apply the same operation to multiple
#Text=Highway makes SIMD/vector programming practical and workable according to these
#Text=**Does what you expect**: Highway is a C++ library with carefully-chosen
#Text=functions that map well to CPU instructions without extensive compiler
#Text=The resulting code is more predictable and robust to code
#Text=**Works on widely-used platforms**: Highway supports five architectures; the
#Text=same application code can target various instruction sets, including those with
#Text=If you would like to use Highway on
#Text=**Flexible to deploy**: Applications using Highway can run on heterogeneous
#Text=clouds or client devices, choosing the best available instruction set at
#Text=Alternatively, developers may choose to target a single instruction set
#Text=In both cases, the application code is the same
#Text=**Suitable for a variety of domains**: Highway provides an extensive set of
#Text=operations, used for image processing (floating-point), compression, video
#Text=analysis, linear algebra, cryptography, sorting and random generation.
#Text=recognise that new use-cases may require additional ops and are happy to add
#Text=them where it makes sense (e.g. no performance cliffs on some architectures).
#Text=you would like to discuss, please file an issue.
#Text=**Rewards data-parallel design**: Highway provides tools such as Gather,
#Text=MaskedLoad, and FixedTag to enable speedups for legacy data structures.

#Text=Note that no such flag is needed for clang and

#Text=When vectorizing a loop, an important question is whether and how to deal with
#Text=a number of iterations ('trip count', denoted `count`) that does not evenly
#Text=For example, it may be necessary to avoid
#Text=writing past the end of an array.
#Text=In this section, let `T` denote the element type and `d = ScalableTag<T>`.
#Text=Assume the loop body is given as a function `template<bool partial, class D>
#Text=void LoopBody(D d, size_t index, size_t max_n)`.
#Text="Strip-mining" is a technique for vectorizing a loop by transforming it into an
#Text=outer loop and inner loop, such that the number of iterations in the inner loop
#Text=Then, the inner loop is replaced with vector
#Text=Highway offers several strategies for loop vectorization:
#Text=    for (size_t i = 0; i < count; i += N) LoopBody<false>(d, i, 0);
#Text=    Here, the template parameter and second function argument are not needed.
#Text=This is the preferred option, unless `N` is in the thousands and vector
#Text=    operations are pipelined with long latencies.
#Text=    supercomputers in the 90s, but nowadays ALUs are cheap and we see most
#Text=    implementations split vectors into 1, 2 or 4 parts, so there is little cost
#Text=    to processing entire vectors even if we do not need all their lanes.
#Text=    this avoids the (potentially large) cost of predication or partial
#Text=    loads/stores on older targets, and does not duplicate code
#Text=*   Process whole vectors and include previously processed elements
#Text=    for (size_t i = 0; i < count; i += N) LoopBody<false>(d, HWY_MIN(i, count - N), 0);
#Text=    This is the second preferred option provided that `count >= N`
#Text=Some elements might be processed twice, but
#Text=    a single code path and full vectorization is usually worth it.
#Text=    `count < N`, it usually makes sense to pad inputs/outputs up to `N`
#Text=    takes care of the loop and remainder handling and you simply define a
#Text=    generic lambda function (C++14) or functor which receives the current vector
#Text=    from the input/output array, plus optionally vectors from up to two extra
#Text=    input arrays, and returns the value to write to the input/output array.
#Text=Here is an example implementing the BLAS function SAXPY (`alpha * x + y`):
#Text=    Transform1(d, x, n, y, [](auto d, const auto v, const auto v1) HWY_ATTR {
#Text=*   Process whole vectors as above, followed by a scalar loop:
#Text=    for (; i + N <= count; i += N) LoopBody<false>(d, i, 0);
#Text=    The template parameter and second function arguments are again not needed.
#Text=This avoids duplicating code, and is reasonable if `count` is large.
#Text=If `count` is small, the second loop may be slower than the next option
#Text=*   Process whole vectors as above, followed by a single call to a modified
#Text=    for (; i + N <= count; i += N) {
#Text=    Now the template parameter and third function argument can be used inside
#Text=    `LoopBody` to non-atomically 'blend' the first `num_remaining` lanes of `v`
#Text=    with the previous contents of memory at subsequent locations:
#Text=    `MaskedLoad(FirstN(d, num_remaining), d, pointer)` loads the first
#Text=    `num_remaining` elements and returns zero in other lanes.
#Text=This is a good default when it is infeasible to ensure vectors are padded,
#Text=In contrast to the scalar loop, only a single final iteration is needed.
#Text=The increased code size from two loop bodies is expected to be worthwhile
#Text=    because it avoids the cost of masking in all but the final iteration.
